summary: Henry P. Lopez was a CIA asset who worked for the Mexico City Station from 1961 to 1966. He was involved in operational activities and approvals in Spain, and his activities, expenses, cover arrangements, and termination settlements with the CIA are documented, including the use of proprietary companies and potential operational deployments. He was later employed as a legal consultant for WUSALINE in New York City. He was also discussed in the context of influencing Fidel Castro and exploiting weaknesses within his regime in 1960. The House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) requested assistance from the CIA to interview Lopez in Mexico in 1978.
significance: Henry P. Lopez is significant in the JFK assassination context because the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) sought to interview him in Mexico, suggesting he may have had information relevant to their investigation. His prior involvement with the CIA, particularly his work in Mexico City and his connection to operations in Spain, could have been of interest to the HSCA.
